lines.text: Enter SIR TOBY BELCH and MARIA

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: What a plague means my niece, to take the death of her brother thus I am sure cares an enemy to life.

lines.speaker: maria
lines.text: By my troth, Sir Toby, you must come in earlier o nights: your cousin, my lady, takes great exceptions to your ill hours.

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: Why, let her except, before excepted.

lines.speaker: maria
lines.text: Ay, but you must confine yourself within the modest limits of order.

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: Confine! Ill confine myself no finer than I am: these clothes are good enough to drink in and so be these boots too: an they be not, let them hang themselves in their own straps.

lines.speaker: maria
lines.text: That quaffing and drinking will undo you: I heard my lady talk of it yesterday and of a foolish knight that you brought in one night here to be her wooer.

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: Who, Sir Andrew Aguecheek

lines.speaker: maria
lines.text: Ay, he.

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: Hes as tall a man as anys in Illyria.

lines.speaker: maria
lines.text: Whats that to the purpose

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: Why, he has three thousand ducats a year.

lines.speaker: maria
lines.text: Ay, but hell have but a year in all these ducats: hes a very fool and a prodigal.

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: Fie, that youll say so! he plays o the violdegamboys, and speaks three or four languages word for word without book, and hath all the good gifts of nature.

lines.speaker: maria
lines.text: He hath indeed, almost natural: for besides that hes a fool, hes a great quarreller: and but that he hath the gift of a coward to allay the gust he hath in quarrelling, tis thought among the prudent he would quickly have the gift of a grave.

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: By this hand, they are scoundrels and subtractors that say so of him. Who are they

lines.speaker: maria
lines.text: They that add, moreover, hes drunk nightly in your company.

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: With drinking healths to my niece: Ill drink to her as long as there is a passage in my throat and drink in Illyria: hes a coward and a coystrill that will not drink to my niece till his brains turn o the toe like a parishtop. What, wench! Castiliano vulgo! for here comes Sir Andrew Agueface.
Enter SIR ANDREW

lines.speaker: sir andrew
lines.text: Sir Toby Belch! how now, Sir Toby Belch!

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: Sweet Sir Andrew!

lines.speaker: sir andrew
lines.text: Bless you, fair shrew.

lines.speaker: maria
lines.text: And you too, sir.

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: Accost, Sir Andrew, accost.

lines.speaker: sir andrew
lines.text: Whats that

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: My nieces chambermaid.

lines.speaker: sir andrew
lines.text: Good Mistress Accost, I desire better acquaintance.

lines.speaker: maria
lines.text: My name is Mary, sir.

lines.speaker: sir andrew
lines.text: Good Mistress Mary Accost,

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: You mistake, knight accost is front her, board her, woo her, assail her.

lines.speaker: sir andrew
lines.text: By my troth, I would not undertake her in this company. Is that the meaning of accost

lines.speaker: maria
lines.text: Fare you well, gentlemen.

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: An thou let part so, Sir Andrew, would thou mightst never draw sword again.

lines.speaker: sir andrew
lines.text: An you part so, mistress, I would I might never draw sword again. Fair lady, do you think you have fools in hand

lines.speaker: maria
lines.text: Sir, I have not you by the hand.

lines.speaker: sir andrew
lines.text: Marry, but you shall have and heres my hand.

lines.speaker: maria
lines.text: Now, sir, thought is free: I pray you, bring your hand to the butterybar and let it drink.

lines.speaker: sir andrew
lines.text: Wherefore, sweetheart whats your metaphor

lines.speaker: maria
lines.text: Its dry, sir.

lines.speaker: sir andrew
lines.text: Why, I think so: I am not such an ass but I can keep my hand dry. But whats your jest

lines.speaker: maria
lines.text: A dry jest, sir.

lines.speaker: sir andrew
lines.text: Are you full of them

lines.speaker: maria
lines.text: Ay, sir, I have them at my fingers ends: marry, now I let go your hand, I am barren.
Exit

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: O knight thou lackest a cup of canary: when did I see thee so put down

lines.speaker: sir andrew
lines.text: Never in your life, I think unless you see canary put me down. Methinks sometimes I have no more wit than a Christian or an ordinary man has: but I am a great eater of beef and I believe that does harm to my wit.

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: No question.

lines.speaker: sir andrew
lines.text: An I thought that, Ild forswear it. Ill ride home tomorrow, Sir Toby.

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: Pourquoi, my dear knight

lines.speaker: sir andrew
lines.text: What is Pourquoi do or not do I would I had bestowed that time in the tongues that I have in fencing, dancing and bearbaiting: O, had I but followed the arts!

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: Then hadst thou had an excellent head of hair.

lines.speaker: sir andrew
lines.text: Why, would that have mended my hair

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: Past question for thou seest it will not curl by nature.

lines.speaker: sir andrew
lines.text: But it becomes me well enough, doest not

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: Excellent it hangs like flax on a distaff and I hope to see a housewife take thee between her legs and spin it off.

lines.speaker: sir andrew
lines.text: Faith, Ill home tomorrow, Sir Toby: your niece will not be seen or if she be, its four to one shell none of me: the count himself here hard by woos her.

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: Shell none o the count: shell not match above her degree, neither in estate, years, nor wit I have heard her sweart. Tut, theres life int, man.

lines.speaker: sir andrew
lines.text: Ill stay a month longer. I am a fellow o the strangest mind i the world I delight in masques and revels sometimes altogether.

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: Art thou good at these kickshawses, knight

lines.speaker: sir andrew
lines.text: As any man in Illyria, whatsoever he be, under the degree of my betters and yet I will not compare with an old man.

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: What is thy excellence in a galliard, knight

lines.speaker: sir andrew
lines.text: Faith, I can cut a caper.

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: And I can cut the mutton tot.

lines.speaker: sir andrew
lines.text: And I think I have the backtrick simply as strong as any man in Illyria.

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: Wherefore are these things hid wherefore have these gifts a curtain before em are they like to take dust, like Mistress Malls picture why dost thou not go to church in a galliard and come home in a coranto My very walk should be a jig I would not so much as make water but in a sinkapace. What dost thou mean Is it a world to hide virtues in I did think, by the excellent constitution of thy leg, it was formed under the star of a galliard.

lines.speaker: sir andrew
lines.text: Ay, tis strong, and it does indifferent well in a flamecoloured stock. Shall we set about some revels

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: What shall we do else were we not born under Taurus

lines.speaker: sir andrew
lines.text: Taurus! Thats sides and heart.

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: No, sir it is legs and thighs. Let me see the caper ha! higher: ha, ha! excellent!
Exeunt
